title: 113_s2417
content: The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" may impose a lifetime ban on members of Congress from lobbying. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" may impose a lifetime ban on former members of Congress from lobbying. The amendment to Section 207(e)(1) of title 18, United States Code, prohibits ex-Senators, ex-House Members, or elected officers from influencing current members or employees of Congress on behalf of any other person. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" imposes a lifetime ban on former members of Congress from lobbying. It prohibits ex-Senators, ex-House Members, or elected officers from influencing current members or employees of Congress on behalf of any other person. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" imposes a lifetime ban on former members of Congress from lobbying. It prohibits ex-Senators, ex-House Members, or elected officers from influencing current members or employees of Congress in their official capacity. Section 207(e)(2) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to reflect these changes. SEC. 3 of the "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2014" extends the ban on former members of Congress from lobbying to 6 years. SEC. 4 focuses on improving the reporting of lobbyists' activities. Section 6 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to create a joint lobbyist disclosure Internet database called lobbyists.gov, maintained by the Secretary of the Senate and the Clerk of the House of Representatives. $100,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2015 for this purpose. Any person who is a registered lobbyist or agent of a foreign principal cannot be hired by a Member or committee of Congress within 6 years of leaving their position if they had substantial lobbying contact. A waiver can be granted by the Committee on Ethics or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct based on a compelling national need. Any registered lobbyist or agent of a foreign principal cannot be hired by a Member or committee of Congress within 6 years of leaving their position if they had substantial lobbying contact. Waivers can be granted by the Committee on Ethics or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct based on a compelling national need. The determination of substantial lobbying contact includes considering if the lobbying contacts were related to pending legislative business, solicitation of earmarks or Federal funding, and coordination of meetings with the Member. When evaluating whether a former lobbyist can be hired by a Member or committee of Congress, consideration is given to their lobbying contacts related to legislative business, earmarks, or Federal funding. Social contacts alone do not constitute substantial lobbying contacts. SEC. 6A. REPORTING BY SUBSTANTIAL LOBBYING ENTITIES. The Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to include reporting requirements for substantial lobbying entities. Substantial lobbying entities must annually report to the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the United States Senate any employees, contractors, or consultants who are former members of Congress or congressional staff meeting specific criteria. The disclosure requirements for former congressional staff members include those who made over $100,000 in a year, worked for at least 4 years, or held specific job titles. Former congressional staff members must disclose if they held job titles such as Chief of Staff, Legislative Director, Staff Director, Counsel, Professional Staff Member, Communications Director, or Press Secretary. The filing should include a brief job description and work experience explanation. The filing required by this section shall contain a brief job description of each employee, individual under contract, or individual providing paid consulting services, along with an explanation of their work experience. The Joint Web site lobbyists.gov will include a searchable database of 'Substantial Lobbying Entities' with qualifying employees and individuals. The Joint Web site lobbyists.gov will have a searchable database called `Substantial Lobbying Entities' with qualifying employees, individuals under contract, or paid consultants. The Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate will provide filings of these entities to the District of Columbia United States Attorney for law enforcement oversight. The Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate will provide filings of substantial lobbying entities to the District of Columbia United States Attorney for law enforcement oversight, to ensure accurate reporting of federal lobbying activities by entities with more than 3 federally registered lobbyists. SEC. 7 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to increase penalties from $200,000 to $500,000.
